You completely misunderstood.

Viktor's gray morality comes from his incredibly advanced technology which can alter the world. Nobody knows if the altered world would be good or evil, because nobody can see that far. His gray morality is the consequence of him being potentially on the edge of madness, but never quite stepping over the edge.

All we ever got in recent lores is him presented as overstepping that edge. Nobody wants that.

Stop spewing attacks backed up by faulty logic.

What do we have? 

"Viktor sought to solve problems inherent to humanity itself, such as physical decay or illogical prejudices." 

* Doesnt seem terrible to me. 

"However, the two reached an impasse when Viktor's design for the next version of the suit included a chemtech implant that would increase the wearer's strength output by tenfold, while also preventing them from getting tired, panicking, or disobeying instructions from their superiors. While Viktor considered this feature a brilliant means of reducing the frequency of construction accidents, Jayce found its indifference toward free will immoral." 

* His reasoning for developing this tech wasnt to be the king of the world - it was so people wouldnt hurt themselves by succumbing to panic and/or disobeying orders as a result of their irrational fear. At the end of the day, Viktor wants to save lives. 

"The two nearly came to blows over the design and ultimately, after Jayce warned the academy of Viktor's invention, Viktor was stripped of his honors and ostracized from Piltover's scientific community."

* We dont know why, exactly, he was stripped of his honrs and ostracized from Piltover. Maybe because Piltover has a very strong (and maybe in Viktor's eyes, illogical?) bias against chemtech? They love hextech but seem to look down on everything and everybody else, especially taking into account all the talk of nobility in Piltover and how they treat those beneath them.

"Since his expulsion from the Piltovan scientific community, Viktor had commenced work on a secret project in Zaun. He'd finally learned how to achieve his dream - how to eradicate disease, hunger, hatred."

* Doesnt paint him as a villain in my eyes. This actually opens up a door to the misunderstood villain theme. 

"Dozens of corpses, their skulls sawed open and hollowed out, their brains transplanted into an army of immobile metal soldiers, hooked up to the now-pulsing crystal." "Their eyes were dead, their faces emotionless. They were definitely Viktor's boys, alright: drugged punks from Zaun's sump level whom Viktor had pumped full of hallucinogens and hypnotics. Chem-stunted thugs who would follow Viktor's every whim whether they wanted to or not." 

* We dont exactly how Viktor got these people - maybe it was by choice, maybe not. After all, these arent noble and heroic folks - they are the lowest level of poor in Zaun, a city plagued by pollution and violence. Maybe their bodies and minds were already destroyed from years of drugs and pollution, and this was the only way to keep them alive. Maybe they were already dead and he found a way to reanimate their brain. After all, if Viktor wanted mindless automatons, he could have made them. If he wanted autonomous robots, he could have made them (He made Blitz, after all). To me, this is the biggest question that could open a lot up for Viktor - **What is the benefit from using a human mind, especially when an automation would have served the exact same purpose without all the hassle? ** An entire army of these "chemslaves" powered by the most powerful crystal in the world was basically brought down by a scholar with no combat training and just a shard of the crystal - an automation army couldnt do worse than that, so whats the purpose behind it? 

* Also, we arent sure whether or not this was a forced experiment or a voluntary one - in League lore, there are lots of people who voluntarily would give up their free will to serve their "greater good", especially with all the military power around. Take a look at the description of Demacia's military: "Their 'zero tolerance' moral code is strictly upheld by civilians and soldiers alike. In combat, this means Demacian troops may not make excuses, flee, or surrender under any circumstance." If thats their highest value, dont you think some soldiers would voluntarily undergo Viktor's experiment so they woujldnt succumb? 

__________________
Lastly, remember what they did with Xerath and Azir. What we have is one side of the story - the story from Jayce's point of view. What we dont see is why Viktor did what he did, similar to how Azir's story doesnt show Xerath's side of things. When you hear the villain's story, suddenly they become more relatable - Xerath went from a psychopath traitor/mass murderer in Azir's story to a poor boy who was brought up a slave, who raised Azir to new heights for the promise of equality and freedom, and was denied that basic right over and over again ("Azir’s face was thunderous as he reminded Xerath that he was a slave and should remember his place." "The soured promise ate into what he was, and what he could have been. Denied a small, simple thing, the right to live his life.")

Xerath's story makes him human, relatable, and ultimately misunderstood as a villain. A simple misunderstanding - Azir, who kept his plans to abolish slavery secret, and Xerath, who felt that Azir lost his moral compass (after all, Azir confined in him everything else) - started the entire feud. 

So basically what I'm saying is dont lose hope for Viktor.

This is Runeterra. They have different moral standards there. Look at piltover, it stifles inventors that it thinks go against the gilded appearance of the city and leave the Zaunites to stew in their own toxins, but many people think that Piltover is okay. Runeterra is a different world than ours, and we can't just push our moral standards off on them.

If the people of Runeterra were to get stories of our World from an omniscient perspective like we get of their world they would see in us in some areas what we see in them.
Piltover is run by very high-minded elitists. The type of people who set trends and dictate how the city is run more then any actual government. You can see this even amongst High Society of our own world, if you know where to look.
Zaun is the darker side of the same coin.  For every Metropolis there is a Gotham, though rarely is one literally on top of the other. Where Metropolis and Piltover are run by their Lex Corps and various Clans, Zaun is run by criminals and gangs much like Gotham.
True. But both societies are fairly corrupt, so people from both sides can't really be put into simple terms like good or evil.
they can be very easily, if you are from one of those camps or agree with them.

My biggest complaint about the new Viktor is how he contradicts himself. 
Why would someone who's life goal is to eradicate organic life and replace it with the near immortal and near perfect works of cybernetics and robotics **be in favor of eradicating free will and thus, the mind?** Free will and free thinking are what elevates humanity. Evolving out of an organic body into a robotic body **requires an intact, living mind to make it worthy of being an evolution. ** Removing the will of the evolved is not Viktor enacting a campaign of ideals to progress humanity to the future he wants, it's creating an army of mindless robots. They put Viktor into the one sided stupid trope that cartoon villains fall into - domination of a mindless world that is unfulfilled and contradictory to being a world leader.

I think at its core, that is what most Viktor fans are truly riled up about, like me I am in the grey and have no real care for what happens to him ( I just want a good story.) But come on, the guy's sole life goal is to make humanity the greatest thing out there, and humanity at its core is free will. It just doesn't fit.

I don't know of any Viktor fans that want him to be a villain. Maybe an anti-hero.

I feel like the problem come from how in the old lore Viktors fatal flaw was that had too much of a moral compass, and because of that the world (and the fact that Zaun doesn't have any morals) broke him. I could totally see him going "You know what, humanity just sucks, the glorious evolution is no longer optional, all your base are belong to us." and that being a logical extension of his character. 

In the new lore it seems to be implied that he was always a piece of work, and that he never had a moral compass to speak of. Which to me kind of lessens the impact of his character, and makes him a lot less relatable.
